title: Idioms & Proverbs
description: Master Moroccan Darija idioms, proverbs, and figurative language

lessons.title: Common Darija Proverbs

vocabulary.arabic: اللي بغا العسل يصبر لقرص النحل
vocabulary.romanized: lli bgha l3sl ysbr l9rss nn7l
vocabulary.english: Who wants honey must endure bee stings

example_sentence.arabic: خاصك تصبر - اللي بغا العسل يصبر لقرص النحل
example_sentence.romanized: khask tsbr - lli bgha l3sl ysbr l9rss nn7l
example_sentence.english: You must be patient - who wants honey must endure bee stings

vocabulary.english: The monkey in his mother's eyes is a gazelle

example_sentence.arabic: كل واحد كيحب ولادو - القرد في عين أمو غزال
example_sentence.romanized: kl wa7d kay7b wlado - l9rd f 3in mmo ghzal
example_sentence.english: Everyone loves their children - the monkey is a gazelle in his mother's eyes

vocabulary.english: What's past is dead (let bygones be bygones)

example_sentence.arabic: ما تفكرش فاللي فات - اللي فات مات
example_sentence.romanized: ma tfkkrsh flli fat - lli fat mat
example_sentence.english: Don't think about the past - what's past is dead

vocabulary.arabic: ضربني و بكى، سبقني و شكى
vocabulary.romanized: drbni w bka, sb9ni w shka
vocabulary.english: He hit me and cried, went ahead and complained

example_sentence.arabic: هو اللي غلط و مع ذلك كيشكي - ضربني و بكى سبقني و شكى
example_sentence.romanized: hwa lli ghlT w m3a dalik kayshki
example_sentence.english: He's the one who's wrong and yet he complains

vocabulary.arabic: اللي ما عندو الفلوس كلامو مسوس
vocabulary.english: Who has no money, his words are worm-eaten

example_sentence.arabic: الفلوس كتعطي القوة - اللي ما عندو الفلوس كلامو مسوس
example_sentence.english: Money gives power

vocabulary.english: One hand doesn't clap (cooperation is needed)

example_sentence.arabic: خاصنا نتعاونو - يد واحدة ما كتصفقش
example_sentence.romanized: khasna nt3awno - ydd wa7da ma katssf9sh
example_sentence.english: We need to cooperate - one hand doesn't clap

vocabulary.english: He cuts his own leg with his knife (self-sabotage)

example_sentence.arabic: كيضر راسو بيدو - كيقطع رجلو بموسو
example_sentence.english: He harms himself

vocabulary.english: Give the fool the stage and he'll dance

example_sentence.arabic: ما تعطيش الفرصة لأي واحد
example_sentence.english: Don't give the opportunity to just anyone

vocabulary.english: Who digs a hole for others falls in it

example_sentence.arabic: ما تديرش الشر - اللي كيحفر للناس كيطيح فيها
example_sentence.english: Don't do evil

vocabulary.english: A sweet word opens the iron gate

example_sentence.arabic: هضر مزيان مع الناس - كلمة حلوة كتفتح باب الحديد
example_sentence.english: Speak well with people

example_sentence.arabic: راسو بحال البغل
example_sentence.english: His head is like a mule's (he's stubborn)

example_sentence.arabic: كنحبك من القلب
example_sentence.english: I love you from the heart

example_sentence.arabic: هاد الراجل طلع ليا فالراس
example_sentence.english: This man got on my nerves

example_sentence.arabic: عندو الزهر بزاف
example_sentence.english: He's very lucky

vocabulary.english: he's messing with his head / manipulating

example_sentence.arabic: ما تخليهش يلعب بعقلك
example_sentence.english: Don't let him manipulate you

grammar.explanation: Darija proverbs often use 'lli' (who/whoever) to start universal truths, rhyme, and metaphor.

examples.arabic: اللي بغا العسل يصبر لقرص النحل
examples.romanized: lli bgha l3sl ysbr l9rss nn7l
examples.english: Who wants honey must endure bee stings

common_mistakes: Proverbs have fixed forms - don't try to modify them

grammar.explanation: Idioms add color: 'Tl3 lia fras' (annoyed me), '3ndo zzhr' (he's lucky), 'raso 9as7' (he's stubborn).

examples.english: This thing got on my nerves!

common_mistakes: Using idioms correctly shows advanced mastery of Darija

grammar.explanation: Darija uses animal metaphors: bghl (mule=stubborn), 7mar (donkey=foolish), ghzal (gazelle=beautiful), dib (wolf=cunning).

examples.english: He's a wolf (cunning), don't trust him

common_mistakes: Animal metaphors can be offensive if used about real people - use carefully

grammar.explanation: Use 'b7al ma 9alu nnas' (as people say), 'kayn wa7d lmathal' (there's a proverb), 'lkbar 9alu' (elders said).

examples.arabic: بحال ما قالو الناس: اللي فات مات
examples.romanized: b7al ma 9alu nnas: lli fat mat
examples.english: As people say: what's past is dead

common_mistakes: Always introduce a proverb with a framing phrase

grammar.explanation: Body idioms: 'Tl3 lia fras' (got on my nerves), 'drb 3la yeddo' (hit on his hand = stopped him), 'kla lkrsh' (ate his stomach = worried too much).

examples.arabic: ضرب على يدو و ما خلاهش يكمل
examples.romanized: drb 3la yddo w ma khllahsh ykml
examples.english: He stopped him and didn't let him continue

common_mistakes: Body idioms are very common in Darija and essential for fluency

phrases.english: What's past is dead, look ahead
A kind word opens the iron gate

exercises.question: What does 'l9rd f 3in mmo ghzal' mean?
exercises.correct_answer: A mother always sees her child as beautiful (parental bias)
exercises.hint: It's about how parents see their children

exercises.question: Translate to Darija: 'Past tense of 'to pass''
What does 'يد واحدة ما كتصفقش' mean?
What does 'كلمة حلوة كتفتح باب الحديد' mean?
Translate: 'As the elders said: patience is the key to relief'
exercises.correct_answer_arabic: بحال ما قالو الكبار: الصبر مفتاح الفرج
exercises.correct_answer_romanized: b7al ma 9alu lkbar: ssbr mfta7 lfrj
exercises.hint: Frame the proverb with 'b7al ma 9alu lkbar'

exercises.question: What animal represents stubbornness in Darija idioms?
exercises.hint: 'raso b7al lbghl' means his head is like a mule's

cultural_notes: Moroccan proverbs (amthal) are a cornerstone of oral culture, passed down through generations. Using them shows deep cultural knowledge.
Many Darija idioms have Amazigh (Berber) origins, reflecting Morocco's multi-cultural linguistic heritage.

lessons.title: Body & Animal Idioms

example_sentence.arabic: ضحكنا حتى طلعات لينا الدموع
example_sentence.english: We laughed until we cried

example_sentence.arabic: كلا الكرش ديالو على الامتحان
example_sentence.english: He worried too much about the exam

example_sentence.arabic: ما تحاولش معاه، راسو ناشف
example_sentence.english: Don't try with him, he's stubborn

example_sentence.arabic: رد البال منها، عندها لسان طويل
example_sentence.english: Watch out for her, she gossips

example_sentence.arabic: دار بحال الحمار
example_sentence.english: He acted foolishly

example_sentence.arabic: هادا ديب، ما تتيقش فيه
example_sentence.english: He's cunning, don't trust him

example_sentence.arabic: بحال النملة، ديما كيخدم
example_sentence.english: Like an ant, always working

example_sentence.arabic: ما تكونش دجاجة!
example_sentence.english: Don't be a coward!

example_sentence.arabic: خلّا مسمار جحا باش يرجع
example_sentence.english: He left an excuse to come back

example_sentence.arabic: ما كيحس بحتى واحد، قلبو حجر
example_sentence.english: He doesn't feel for anyone, heart of stone

example_sentence.arabic: هاداك فمو مسدود، ما كيقول والو
example_sentence.romanized: hadak fmmo msddud, ma kay9ul walu
example_sentence.english: That one keeps his mouth shut, says nothing

grammar.explanation: Body idioms: 'raso nashf' (stubborn), '3ndo lsan Twil' (gossips), '9lbo kbir' (generous), 'yddo khfifa' (steals/light-fingered).

examples.english: He has a big heart, he helps everyone

common_mistakes: Body idioms are central to Darija expression - learn them to sound natural

grammar.explanation: Compare with 'b7al' + animal: 'b7al l7mar' (like a donkey/stupid), 'b7al nnmla' (like an ant/hardworking), 'b7al ssb3' (like a lion/brave).

examples.arabic: كيخدم بحال النملة من الصباح حتى الليل
examples.romanized: kaykhdm b7al nnmla mn ssba7 7tta llil
examples.english: He works like an ant from morning to night

common_mistakes: Be careful with animal comparisons about real people - some are offensive

grammar.explanation: 'ma...walu' (nothing at all), 'ma...7tta shi 7aja' (not a single thing): 'ma 3ndo walu' (he has nothing).

examples.arabic: ما فهمت والو من اللي قال
examples.english: I understood nothing of what he said

common_mistakes: 'walu' is stronger than just 'sh' for negation emphasis

phrases.english: That one is as stubborn as a mule
He worries too much about the kids

exercises.question: What does 'raso nashf' mean?
exercises.hint: About someone who won't change their mind

exercises.question: Translate to Darija: 'A body part used for talking'

cultural_notes: Animal metaphors in Darija reflect Morocco's agricultural heritage. Farm animals (mule, donkey, hen) appear most frequently in idioms.
The character Juha (j7a) appears in many Moroccan stories and idioms. 'Msmar j7a' (Juha's nail) comes from a story where Juha sold his house but kept one nail, using it as an excuse to return.

lessons.title: Wisdom & Life Proverbs

vocabulary.english: patience is the key to relief

example_sentence.arabic: أصبر، الصبر مفتاح الفرج
example_sentence.english: Be patient, patience is the key to relief

vocabulary.english: who does good will find it

example_sentence.arabic: دير الخير و نساه - اللي داير الخير يلقاه
example_sentence.romanized: dir lkhir w nsah - lli dayr lkhir yl9ah
example_sentence.english: Do good and forget it - who does good will find it

example_sentence.arabic: الحمد لله على كل حال، خاصنا نصبرو
example_sentence.english: Praise God in all circumstances, we must be patient

example_sentence.arabic: الضيف ديف الله، مرحبا بيه
example_sentence.english: The guest is God's guest, welcome him

vocabulary.english: who comes early grinds (early bird gets the worm)

example_sentence.arabic: سير بكري، اللي بكري يطحن
example_sentence.english: Go early, the early bird gets the worm

example_sentence.arabic: ما كاين غير الله، توكلنا عليه
example_sentence.english: There is only God, we trust in Him

example_sentence.arabic: ما تيأسش، الأيام دول
example_sentence.english: Don't despair, fortunes change

vocabulary.english: if you want to succeed, work

example_sentence.arabic: ما كاين طريق ساهل، إلا بغيت تنجح خدم
example_sentence.romanized: ma kayn Tri9 sahl, ila bghit tnj7 khdm
example_sentence.english: There's no easy path, if you want to succeed, work

vocabulary.english: the house owner knows best what's in it

example_sentence.arabic: ما تحكمش على الناس، مول الدار أدرى بما فيها
example_sentence.romanized: ma t7kmsh 3la nnas, mul ddar adra bma fiha
example_sentence.english: Don't judge people, they know their own situation

vocabulary.english: words of the night are erased by day (promises made at night are forgotten)

example_sentence.arabic: ما تتيقش فاللي قال ليك فالليل
example_sentence.english: Don't trust what he told you at night

grammar.explanation: Frame advice with proverbs: 'b7al ma 9alu...' (as they say...), 'l7kmma 9alat...' (wisdom says...). Follow with the proverb.

examples.arabic: بحال ما قالو الناس: إلا بغيت تنجح، خدم
examples.romanized: b7al ma 9alu nnas: ila bghit tnj7, khdm
examples.english: As people say: if you want to succeed, work

common_mistakes: Proverbs are most effective when naturally woven into conversation

grammar.explanation: Many proverbs use conditional structure: 'lli + verb' (whoever does), 'ila + verb' (if one does).

examples.arabic: اللي داير الخير يلقاه، و اللي داير الشر يلقاه
examples.romanized: lli dayr lkhir yl9ah, w lli dayr shshr yl9ah
examples.english: Whoever does good finds it, and whoever does evil finds it

common_mistakes: 'lli' starts universal truths; 'ila' starts conditional statements

grammar.explanation: Religious phrases are woven into Darija: 'l7amdulillah' (thank God), 'inshallah' (God willing), 'tbarkllah' (God bless), 'la 7awla wala 9uwwata illa billah' (there is no power except with God).

examples.english: God bless you, may God protect you

common_mistakes: These expressions are cultural, not necessarily religious indicators - all Moroccans use them

phrases.arabic: الصبر مفتاح الفرج، أصبر و غادي تشوف
phrases.romanized: ssbr mfta7 lfrj, asbr w ghadi tshuf
phrases.english: Patience is key, be patient and you'll see
Do good and forget about it
Night's words are erased by day

exercises.question: What does 'ssbr mfta7 lfrj' mean?
exercises.correct_answer: Patience is the key to relief

exercises.question: What does 'دير الخير و نساه' mean?
What does 'tbarkllah' express?
exercises.hint: Said when you admire something or someone

cultural_notes: Moroccan proverbs reflect a worldview that combines Islamic faith, practical wisdom, and social harmony. They are used by all generations.
Religious expressions like 'tbarkllah', 'l7amdulillah', and 'inshallah' are cultural markers used by all Moroccans regardless of religiosity level.

fill_blanks.english: He who wants honey must endure the bee stings
Do good and forget about it
Education is the key to progress

cultural_quiz.question: What is the significance of proverbs (amthal) in Moroccan culture?
cultural_quiz.correct_answer: They are a vital part of oral tradition, encoding cultural wisdom passed through generations
distractors: They are borrowed from other cultures
cultural_quiz.explanation: Moroccan proverbs reflect centuries of collective wisdom and are used daily in conversation to make points, give advice, and express truths.
